elements.content: To determine the influence of reaction conditions on the formation of metal−organic frameworks, a series of Co(II)/H2tbip/bpp complexes, {[Co2(tbip)2(H2O)6]·8H2O} n (1), {[Co(tbip)(bpp)(H2O)]2·4H2O} n (2), {[Co(tbip)(bpp)]·H2O} n (3), {[Co2(H2O)(tbip)(Htbip)2(bpp)2]·0.5(H2tbip)·0.5H2O} n (4), {[Co3(OH)(tbip)2(Htbip)(bpp)]} n (5) (H2tbip = 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid, bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane), have been synthesized through the hydrothermal reaction of cobalt(II) acetate, H2tbip, and bpp under different temperatures and pH conditions. The diverse product structures show the marked sensitivity of the structural chemistry of the aromatic carboxylate ligand to synthesis conditions. Polymer 1, which features a three-dimensional (3D) framework with CdSO4 topology, has carboxylate bridging polymeric chains spanning two different directions and bridging water molecules between these chains, and is formed at pH = 4 at 120 °C. At pH = 6, a one-dimensional tube-like structure of 2 is formed. Further increase of the pH value to 7.5 results in a two-dimensional corrugated network structure of 3. Raising the temperature to 160 °C results in the formation of binuclear [Co2(H2O)]4+ and trinuclear cluster node [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ secondary building units in 4 and 5. 4 has a 3D coordination network having alternate opposite chiral layers constructed from {[Co2(H2O)]4+-bpp -tbip-} n single-helical chains, whereas compound 5 exhibits a 3D network based on the [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ node. Both compounds have α-Po topology. Interestingly, the trinuclear cluster node in 5 has a unique combination between pentacoordinated, tetrahedrally coordinated, and octahedrally coordinated Co(II) sites, which has never been reported in other μ3-hydroxyl-bridged trinuclear or tetranuclear cobalt clusters. The thermal stabilities of 1, 2, and 4 have been studied by means of thermogravimetric analysis. Preliminary X-ray powder diffraction studies of 4 indicate that the framework is stable even to the loss of both guest H2tbip and coordinated water molecules. The magnetic properties of 1, 4, and 5 have been investigated and discussed in detail.

elements.content: A series of Co(II) coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a one-dimensional tube-like chain to three-dimensional coordination polymeric networks by the employment of H2tbip and bpp ligands. The structural differences among these complexes highlight the effects of temperature and pH value on framework formation of the complexes.
elements.clean_text: A series of Co(II) coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a one-dimensional tube-like chain to three-dimensional coordination polymeric networks by the employment of H2tbip and bpp ligands. The structural differences among these complexes highlight the effects of temperature and pH value on framework formation of the complexes.

elements.content: The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is an interesting research field. This not only stems from their potential application as functional materials but also from their intriguing structural topologies. An effective and facile approach for the synthesis of such complexes is still the appropriate choice of well-designed organic ligands as bridges or terminal groups with metal ions or metal clusters as nodes. Among the various ligands, organic aromatic polycarboxylates have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal−organic compounds. In comparison to the 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid ligands, 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid remains largely unexplored. However, H2tbip may provide the potential to form unexpected, unpredictable, and interesting structures because the steric hindrance of the bulky tert-butyl may affect the coordination abilities and modes of related carboxylic groups.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of coordination polymers based upon assembly of metal ions and multifunctional organic ligands is an interesting research field. This not only stems from their potential application as functional materials but also from their intriguing structural topologies. An effective and facile approach for the synthesis of such complexes is still the appropriate choice of well-designed organic ligands as bridges or terminal groups with metal ions or metal clusters as nodes. Among the various ligands, organic aromatic polycarboxylates have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal-organic compounds. In comparison to the 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid ligands, 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid remains largely unexplored. However, H2tbip may provide the potential to form unexpected, unpredictable, and interesting structures because the steric hindrance of the bulky tert-butyl may affect the coordination abilities and modes of related carboxylic groups.

elements.content: On the other hand, the self-assembly of supramolecules and coordination polymers is influenced by many factors, such as the metal-to-ligand molar ratio, the coordinative function of the ligands, the type of metal ions, the presence of solvent molecules, organic guest molecules, reaction temperature, counterion, and pH value of the solution. Although a large number of polycarboxylate-based coordination polymers have been synthesized, systematic investigation of external physical or chemical stimuli effects on the structures of polycarboxylate-based coordination polymers remains rare. Thus, it is still a great challenge to obtain the predicted products at this stage. One approach is to perform a series of reactions in similar conditions with only one factor varied. In such a case, the diversity in assembly and functionality of MOFs can be exclusively attributed to the change of the factor.

elements.content: In our previous work, we have shown the pH and temperature effects on the structures of a series of N-[(3-carboxyphenyl)-sulfonyl]glycine-based coordination polymers by a typical solution−mixed method. As part of our ongoing interest in understanding the ability of temperature and pH value to direct the assembly of metal−organic systems, in this work we investigate the formation of five new coordination polymers in the Co−H2tbip-bpp mixed ligand system under hydrothermal conditions. The influence of the temperature and pH value on the final structure of the assemblies is discussed, and the thermal stability as well as the magnetic properties are also reported.
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, we have shown the pH and temperature effects on the structures of a series of N-[(3-carboxyphenyl)-sulfonyl]glycine-based coordination polymers by a typical solution-mixed method. As part of our ongoing interest in understanding the ability of temperature and pH value to direct the assembly of metal-organic systems, in this work we investigate the formation of five new coordination polymers in the Co-H2tbip-bpp mixed ligand system under hydrothermal conditions. The influence of the temperature and pH value on the final structure of the assemblies is discussed, and the thermal stability as well as the magnetic properties are also reported.

elements.content: All reagents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen atoms were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra (4000 to 400 cm−1) were recorded by using KBr pellet on an Avatar 360 E. S. P. IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG) were carried out on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer with a scanning rate of four degrees per minute. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured using a MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal’s constants for all constituent atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents used in the syntheses were of analytical grade. Elemental analyses for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen atoms were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. The infrared spectra (4000 to 400 cm-1) were recorded by using KBr pellet on an Avatar 360 E. S. P. IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TG) were carried out on a STA449C integration thermal analyzer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer with a scanning rate of four degrees per minute. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured using a MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. Diamagnetic corrections were made with Pascal's constants for all constituent atoms.

elements.content: {[Co2(tbip)2(H2O)6]·8H2O} n (1). A mixture of 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid (0.2 mmol, 45 mg), 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane (0.1 mmol, 20 mg) and Co(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 24 mg) in distilled water (15 mL) (pH = 4) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24 h. Red block crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 16.5 mg, 41%. Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C24H52Co2O22 C 35.55, H 6.47; found C 35.64, H 6.39.IR (cm−1): 3372 m, 2959 m, 1607 m, 1530 s, 1452 m, 1371s, 814 m, 751 m, 725 m.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of 1−5 were carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using ϕ/ω scan technique at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains. A full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 was carried out using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located by Fourier map, and then refined by riding mode. The R values of compound 2 are slightly larger for its poor quality. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1−5 are listed in Table and , . Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers: 694007−694011.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of 1-5 were carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromated MoΚα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using ϕ/ω scan technique at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97. The hydrogen atoms were assigned with common isotropic displacement factors and included in the final refinement by use of geometrical restrains. A full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 was carried out using SHELXL-97. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located by Fourier map, and then refined by riding mode. The R values of compound 2 are slightly larger for its poor quality. The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1-5 are listed in Table  and , . Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. CCDC reference numbers: 694007-694011.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 has a 3D network linked by both tbip and water molecules. As illustrated in Figure a, the coordination environment around the Co(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with three trans angles ranging from 90.20° to 93.80°, where each Co ion is six-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different tbip ligands and four water molecules. The Co−O(water) bond lengths are 2.0597(12), 2.0617(12), 2.1902(11), 2.1906(11) Å and the Co−O(carboxylate) bond lengths are 2.0873(10) and 2.0876 (10) Å, respectively. Remarkably, the structure of 1 consists of one-dimensional (1D) carboxylate bridging polymeric chains spanning two different directions, which displays a quite fascinating supramolecular organization. As shown in Figure a, [Co(H2O)4]2+ units are joined by tbip spacers to generate a 1D linear chain with a period of 11.01 Å. These polymeric chains are further arranged on parallel levels in different propagating directions thus resulting in an ABAB sequence. These chains are then cross-linked to one another by bridging water molecules (Figure b) into a 3D network with CdSO4 topology (Figure c), and featuring two types of rectangular channels (Figures d,e). The tert-butyl groups of the tbip ligands protrude inside the voids of one type of channel and another type of channel encapsulates free water as guest molecules. The effective free volume of 1 was calculated by PLATON analysis as 31.8% of the crystal volume (1254 out of the 3940 Å3 unit cell volume). The formation of a 3D structure via M−O(water) interactions between chains that propagate in two noncoplanar directions is unprecedented.

Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

{[Co2(tbip)2(H2O)6]⋅8H2O} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 has a 3D network linked by both tbip and water molecules. As illustrated in Figure a, the coordination environment around the Co(II) ion can be described as a distorted octahedron with three trans angles ranging from 90.20° to 93.80°, where each Co ion is six-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different tbip ligands and four water molecules. The Co-O(water) bond lengths are 2.0597(12), 2.0617(12), 2.1902(11), 2.1906(11) Å and the Co-O(carboxylate) bond lengths are 2.0873(10) and 2.0876 (10) Å, respectively. Remarkably, the structure of 1 consists of one-dimensional (1D) carboxylate bridging polymeric chains spanning two different directions, which displays a quite fascinating supramolecular organization. As shown in Figure a, [Co(H2O)4]2+ units are joined by tbip spacers to generate a 1D linear chain with a period of 11.01 Å. These polymeric chains are further arranged on parallel levels in different propagating directions thus resulting in an ABAB sequence. These chains are then cross-linked to one another by bridging water molecules (Figure b) into a 3D network with CdSO4 topology (Figure c), and featuring two types of rectangular channels (Figures d,e). The tert-butyl groups of the tbip ligands protrude inside the voids of one type of channel and another type of channel encapsulates free water as guest molecules. The effective free volume of 1 was calculated by PLATON analysis as 31.8% of the crystal volume (1254 out of the 3940 Å3 unit cell volume). The formation of a 3D structure via M-O(water) interactions between chains that propagate in two noncoplanar directions is unprecedented.

elements.content: Compound 2 is a 1D tube-like polymer. The asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically unique Co(II) ions, two tbip, two bpp, two coordinated water molecules, and four guest water molecules. All carboxylic groups of H2tbip are deprotonated, in agreement with the IR data in which no characteristic absorption bands of the -COOH group at 1700−1750 cm−1 are observed. The two Co(II) ions assume similar distorted octahedral environments. The six atoms coordinated to each Co(II) ion come from two nitrogen atoms of two bpp and three oxygen atoms from two different tbip as well as one water molecule. The Co−O and Co−N bond lengths are in the range of 1.997(6)−2.277(5) and 2.130(7)−2.157(8) Å, respectively. The basic building block of this structure is the dinuclear [Co2(bpp)2]4+ entity, in which two bpp link two metal nodes into a 24-membered ring in head-to-tail mode with the Co−Co distance being 12.486 Å (Figure a). Such [Co2(bpp)2]4+ units are interconnected through alternate chelating bis-bidentate and bis-monodentate tbip anions (Schemes a,b) to yield a 1D tube-like chain along the a direction with the cross dimension of the hexagonal channel being 6.5 × 12.5 Å (Figure b), which is comparable to other reported 1D nanotubular coordination polymers.

elements.content: Two kinds of hydrogen bonds are observed: (a) hydrogen bonds between coordinated water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(10)−H(3W)···O(7) 2.669(8) Å, O(9)−H(1W)···O(6) 2.691(8) Å); and (b) hydrogen bonds between coordinated water molecules and chelating coordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O(10)−H(4W)···O(1) 2.803(7) Å, O(9)−H(2W)···O(4) 2.824(7) Å). Thus the 1D tube-like chains are further stacked into a 2D supramolecular structure by these hydrogen bonds (Figure c).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 3 consists of one Co(II) ion, one tbip, one bpp, and a guest water molecule. Each Co(II) ion is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two bpp molecules and two oxygen atoms from two tbip ligands. The Co−O bond lengths, 1.965(3) and 1.988(3) Å, are within the range reported for tetrahedral environments. The Co−N bond lengths, 2.056(3) and 2.088(3) Å, are similar to those found in other tetrahedral cobalt complexes of bpp (Co−N: 2.047−2.048 Å) and are shorter than those found in octahedral bpp complexes (2.136−2.140 Å). The coordination geometry of the cobalt ion is a distorted tetrahedron with angles ranging from 94.01° (O(1)−Co(1)−N(2)) to 111.05° (O(1)−Co(1)−O(4)). Each tbip in 3 adopts the bis-monodentated coordination mode (Scheme a) to connect two adjacent cobalt ions forming a 1D chain (Figure a). The 1D chains are then linked by bpp molecules to result in a 2D corrugated network structure, as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 4 exhibits a 3D network consisting of dinuclear cobalt [Co2(H2O)]4+ cluster nodes, bpp, bridging tbip and Htbip, monodentate Htbip, and free H2tbip molecules. The bpp molecule and tert-butyl group of Htbip are disordered over two sites. For clarity, only one of these sites is shown in Figure . The two Co(II) ions in 4 are both six-coordinated with a distorted octahedral geometry (Figure a). The six atoms coordinated to each Co(II) ion come from two nitrogen atoms of two bpp ligands and three oxygen atoms from three different 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid ligands, as well as one bridging water molecule. It is noteworthy that one of the coordinated oxygen atoms of Co2 comes from a monodentate Htbip ligand, while that of Co1 comes from a bridging Htbip ligand. The Co−O and Co−N bond lengths are in the range of 2.027(3)−2.189(4) Å and 2.167(5)−2.174(5) Å, respectively, which are in the normal range of those observed in cobalt (II) carboxylate complexes containing bpp. The H2tbip ligands are wholly and partly deprotonated and exist in the tbip, Htbip, and free H2tbip forms which is a rare case in the construction of polycarboxylate MOFs. The tbip ligand serves as a three-connected node to coordinate with three cobalt(II) ions through its two carboxylates in bridging and monodentate modes (Scheme c). One Htbip ligand acts as a bis-monodentate mode to bridge two Co(II) ions by one carboxylate group, while the other Htbip ligand coordinates with cobalt(II) ion in a monodentate mode (Scheme d,e).

elements.content: The Co(1) and Co(2) ions are linked together to form a binuclear [Co2(H2O)]4+ cluster where water and tbip both act as bridging ligands. The dinuclear SBUs are linked into extended helical chains via the tbip and bpp ligands. Each helical chain results from metal−ligand interactions and can be described as ([Co2(H2O)]4+ cluster-bpp-tbip-) n (Figure b). The pitch of the helical chain is the same as the length of the a-axis. These helical chains are then interconnected through the dinuclear cobalt clusters to generate a layer with (4,4) topology (with the clusters acting as the nodes). All helices have the same handedness in the same layer (Figure b,c and , ). Adjacent layers possess opposite chirality so that the compound is overall achiral, as shown in Figure d. These 2D chiral layers with opposite chirality are then cross-linked by the second flexible bpp spacer which acts as a pillar, to give a 3D framework with a distorted 6-connected α-Po topology (again, the clusters act as the nodes) (, ). The bidentate and monodentate coordinated Htbip ligands protrude inside the voids of one type of channel, leaving only the other type of channel open. In fact, the uncoordinated ends of these two types of Htbip ligands form carboxyate dimer type hydrogen bonding interactions in which a bidentate Htbip hydrogen bonds to a monodentate Htbip on a neighboring cluster. Thus, these form a hydrogen bonding link between adjacent clusters. Each of these bridges runs parallel to, and connects the same pairs of clusters, as the bpp bridges within the sheets.

elements.content: The open channels encapsulate free H2tbip as guest molecules (Figure d,e). The effective free volume of 4 was calculated by PLATON analysis to be 14.4% of the crystal volume (990.1 out of the 6890.3 Å3 unit cell volume). It was noted that the 3D layer-pillared architecture was common in the assembly of porous coordination polymers with metal-carboxylate sheets always as layers and bidentate pyridyl as pillar ligands. It is rarely observed when bicarboxylate and bidentate pyridyl are simultaneously used to build 2D sheets.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 5 exhibits a 3D network composed of the trinuclear [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ cluster nodes, bpp and tbip (Htbip) bridging ligands (Figure a). There are three crystallographic independent cobalt atoms: Co1 adopts a distorted tetrahedral [O4] coordination environment, which is coordinated by three carboxylic oxygen atoms from three tbip ligands and one oxygen atom from a μ3-hydroxyl group. Co2 adopts a distorted octahedral [O5N] coordination geometry with three carboxylic oxygen atoms from three tbip ligands, one carboxylic oxygen atom from a Htbip ligand, one μ3-hydroxyl group and one nitrogen atom of a bpp ligand. The Co2−N distance is 2.1278(19) Å and the Co2−O distances (from 2.0533(15) to 2.2464(16) Å) are larger than the Co1−O bond lengths (from 1.9463(17) to 2.0056(15) Å). Co3 is five coordinated [O4N] and resides in a trigonal-bipyramidal coordination environment. Three oxygen atoms, O7, O9, and O12 from three tbip ligands form the equatorial plane and the apical positions are occupied by O13 and N1 from a μ3-hydroxyl group and a bpp ligand with a O13−Co3−N1 bond angle of 178.82°. The distances of Co···Co bridged by the μ3-hydroxyl group are 3.287, 3.334, and 3.365 Å, respectively. It is noteworthy that the [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ cluster in 5 is the only example constructed from three cobalt atoms showing not only the octahedral geometry but also the tetrahedral and trigonal-bipyramidal coordination environment, although many other μ3-hydroxyl-bridged trinuclear or tetranuclear cobalt clusters that generally possess only one or two types of coordination configuration had been observed before.

elements.content: The tbip (Htbip) ligands exhibit two kinds of coordination modes, as shown in Scheme a,f. In the first mode, two carboxylate groups act as bis-monodentate modes to bridge two Co atoms. In the second mode, both carboxylate groups act as bidentate modes to bridge four Co atoms together. On the basis of these connection modes, all trinuclear Co clusters are linked by six bridging tbip (Htbip) ligands to form 2D (4,4) layers parallel to the [001] direction (clusters act as nodes), as shown in Figure b. The 2D sheets are further connected by bpp ligands coordinating to the trinuclear SBUs to form a 3D framework with a distorted 6-connected α-Po topology (, ). The structure contains close-packed 1D open channels along the a axis. The diameter of these channels is sufficiently small that they are highly stable without guest molecules. All three methyl groups of the tbip ligands are disordered and protrude into the channels. Measurement of the shortest distance of carbon atoms of two opposite tert-butyl groups is 3.765 Å (Figure c,d). The effective free volume of 5 was calculated by PLATON analysis is 11.4% of the crystal volume (296.1 out of the 2597.8 Å3 unit cell volume).

elements.content: Our aim is to investigate the effects of the temperature and pH value on the self-assembly of supramolecules and coordination polymers. H2tbip, bpp, and Co(II) were selected as starting materials in our study. The synthetic strategy for the Co(II)-H2tbip/bpp system is schematically depicted in Scheme . Complexes 1−3 were obtained under similar reactions but at different pH values that were adjusted by the addition of NaOH. We first carried out the reaction at a pH value of 4 at 120 °C, and compound 1 with a 3D network was obtained. Notably, bpp does not appear in 1. However, without bpp, the directed reaction of H2tbip and Co(OAc)2·4H2O under the same conditions generated unidentified red powders, which suggests that bpp plays an important template role in the formation of 1. Similar situations also occur in other systems. The successful isolation of 1 prompted us to prepare other Co(II) complexes of H2tbip and bpp through altering reaction-influencing factors. When we raised the pH value to 6, compound 2 with a 1D tube-like structure was obtained. If the pH value was raised to 7.5, compound 3 with a 2D corrugated layer was isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity and Synthesis Chemistry

Our aim is to investigate the effects of the temperature and pH value on the self-assembly of supramolecules and coordination polymers. H2tbip, bpp, and Co(II) were selected as starting materials in our study. The synthetic strategy for the Co(II)-H2tbip/bpp system is schematically depicted in Scheme . Complexes 1-3 were obtained under similar reactions but at different pH values that were adjusted by the addition of NaOH. We first carried out the reaction at a pH value of 4 at 120 °C, and compound 1 with a 3D network was obtained. Notably, bpp does not appear in 1. However, without bpp, the directed reaction of H2tbip and Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O under the same conditions generated unidentified red powders, which suggests that bpp plays an important template role in the formation of 1. Similar situations also occur in other systems. The successful isolation of 1 prompted us to prepare other Co(II) complexes of H2tbip and bpp through altering reaction-influencing factors. When we raised the pH value to 6, compound 2 with a 1D tube-like structure was obtained. If the pH value was raised to 7.5, compound 3 with a 2D corrugated layer was isolated.

elements.content: At an enhanced temperature (160 °C), two 3D MOFs with [Co2(H2O)]4+ or [Co3(μ3-OH)]5+ SBUs were formed under different pH values. In comparison with compounds 1, 2, and 3, it has been shown that the hydrothermal temperature has a critical impact on the constructuion of different MOFs. On the basis of the synthetic conditions of 4 and 5, the structural differences between 4 and 5 are clearly related to the pH of the reaction. The effect of pH on the structures of these two complexes is not only through the pH value of the reaction influencing the deprotonation of the organic acid but also by introducing a hydroxyl group at a higher pH value. Observations described above suggest that a suitable pH value and enhanced temperature favor the formation of high-dimensional reaction products.

elements.content: Furthermore, in order to investigate the effect of the bulky tert-butyl group in self-assembly, we used m-isophthalic acid and 5-nitroisophthalic acid instead of H2tbip under the same hydrothermal conditions. Unfortunately, the expected results were not obtained. Instead, we found a 4-fold interpenetrated adamantanoid structure {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O} n (OH-BDC = 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid) which is different from complexes 1−5 and has been reported by Cao et al. Thus, although the carboxylic coordination sites of H2tbip and OH-BDC or NO2−BDC are very similar, their coordination chemistries are obviously different presumably due to steric hindrance of the bulky tert-butyl skeleton.

PXRD and Thermal Analysis

In order to check the phase purity of these compounds, the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns of compounds 1-5 were checked at room temperature. As shown in , , the peak positions of the simulated and experimental XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other, demonstrating the good phase purity of the compounds.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted to study the thermal stability of 1−5, which is an important parameter for metal−organic framework materials (, ). The TGA curve for 1 suggested that the first weight loss of 31.82% in the region of 30−130 °C corresponded to the loss of eight lattice waters and six coordinated waters per formula unit (calcd. 31.12%). The residual framework started to decompose beyond 130 °C with a series of complicated weight losses and did not stop until heating ended at 750 °C. The TGA curve of 2 showed an initial weight loss of 12.86% below 320 °C corresponding to the removal of the solvent and coordinated water molecules (calcd. 10.17%), followed by a series of weight loss after that temperature. The TG curve of 3 showed that an initial weight loss in the temperature range 30−301 °C, which was due to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (weight loss of 3.69% (calcd. 3.65%)). The further weight loss represented the decomposition of the material. Complex 4 showed a weight loss of 11.1% below 270 °C, which closely matches the weight loss of 10.5% for removing half a H2tbip, half a guest water molecule, and one coordinated water molecule per formula unit from the framework, which is also in agreement with the results of elemental analysis.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1, 4, and 5 were measured in the 2−300 K temperature range, and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χM T products of 1 (Figure a) and 4 (Figure b) continuously decrease, which suggests that antiferromagnetic interactions are operative in 1 and 4. The experimental χM T values of 1 and 4 at room temperature are 2.81 and 4.68 cm3 K mol−1, respectively, which are larger than an uncoupled (1.87 cm3 K mol−1) and two isolated spin-only Co2+ cations (3.75 cm3 K mol−1). This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1 and 4 both obey the Curie−Weiss law above 50 K with θ = −34 K, C = 2.58 cm3·K/mol, R = 2.5 × 10−3 for 1 and θ = −26 K, C = 4.38 cm3·K/mol, R = 1.98 × 10−4 for 4. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin−orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1, 4, and 5 were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range, and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χM T products of 1 (Figure a) and 4 (Figure b) continuously decrease, which suggests that antiferromagnetic interactions are operative in 1 and 4. The experimental χM T values of 1 and 4 at room temperature are 2.81 and 4.68 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are larger than an uncoupled (1.87 cm3 K mol-1) and two isolated spin-only Co2+ cations (3.75 cm3 K mol-1). This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1 and 4 both obey the Curie-Weiss law above 50 K with θ = -34 K, C = 2.58 cm3⋅K/mol, R = 2.5 × 10-3 for 1 and θ = -26 K, C = 4.38 cm3⋅K/mol, R = 1.98 × 10-4 for 4. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.

elements.content: Because of the lack of an appropriate analytical expression for an anisotropic model of this complicated system, a Heisenberg model could be used approximately based on the structure data. According to the structure of 1, it could be presumed that the main magnetic interactions between the metal centers might happen between two water bridged Co(II) ions (Co···Co distance: 4.029 Å), whereas the superexchange interactions between Co(II) ions through the tbip ligand bridge can be ignored because of the long Co···Co separation (11.060 Å). The magnetic susceptibility data were fitted assuming that the water bridges Co(II) ions to form a uniform chain with exchange constant J and then tbip connect the chains to form a 3D structure with an exchange constant zJ′. The susceptibility data were thus approximately analyzed by a chain mode of spin S = 3/2. The following qq is induced from the Hamiltonian Ĥ = −JS 1 S 2 χ M = N g 2 β 2 S ( S + 1 ) 3 KT 1 + μ 1 − μ where μ(K) = coth(K) − 1/K; K = 2JS(S + 1)/KT, S = 3/2.

elements.content:
The least-squares analysis of magnetic susceptibility data led to J = −1.8 cm−1, g = 2.32, zJ′ = −0.25 cm−1, and R = 7.1 × 10−3.

The experimental χM T value of 5 (Figure c) at room temperature is 6.75 cm3 K mol−1, higher than the spin value expected for three uncoupled high-spin Co(II) ion. The χM T values steadily decrease with decreasing temperature to reach a minimum value of 4.36 cm3 K mol−1 at 43 K. Between 50 and 300 K, the magnetic susceptibilities can be fitted to the Curie−Weiss law with θ = −22 K, C = 7.1 cm3·K/mol, R = 2.3 × 10−3, thus indicating an overall antiferromagnetic interaction between the Co(II) ions. Upon further cooling, the χM T values increase up to maximum of 4.92 cm3·K/mol at 19 K and then decrease with decreasing temperature. This effect is probably related to a spin canted antiferromagnetic behavior with a weak ferromagnetic ordering taking place below the Neel temperature.

elements.content: A series of Co(II) coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a 1D tube-like chain to 3D coordination polymeric networks by the employment of H2tbip and bpp ligands. The structural differences among 1−5 highlight the effects of temperature and pH value on framework formation of the complexes. Moreover, further comparison of structures with related ligand complexes has been performed, and it shows that the steric bulk of H2tbip plays an important factor in influencing the structures of its complexes. The thermal stability and magnetic properties have also been investigated. The successful preparation of the five different complexes provides a valuable approach for the construction of other coordination polymers with diverse structures under different reaction conditions. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis such crystalline materials with H2tbip and other N,N′-donor building blocks are underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of Co(II) coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions which exhibit a systematic variation of architectures from a 1D tube-like chain to 3D coordination polymeric networks by the employment of H2tbip and bpp ligands. The structural differences among 1-5 highlight the effects of temperature and pH value on framework formation of the complexes. Moreover, further comparison of structures with related ligand complexes has been performed, and it shows that the steric bulk of H2tbip plays an important factor in influencing the structures of its complexes. The thermal stability and magnetic properties have also been investigated. The successful preparation of the five different complexes provides a valuable approach for the construction of other coordination polymers with diverse structures under different reaction conditions. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis such crystalline materials with H2tbip and other N,N'-donor building blocks are underway in our laboratory.

{[Co2(tbip)2(H2O)6]·8H2O} n (1). A mixture of 5-tert-butyl isophthalic acid (0.2 mmol, 45 mg), 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane (0.1 mmol, 20 mg) and Co(OAc)2·4H2O (0.1 mmol, 24 mg) in distilled water (15 mL) (pH = 4) was placed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 120 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature over 24 h. Red block crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 16.5 mg, 41%. Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C24H52Co2O22 C 35.55, H 6.47; found C 35.64, H 6.39.IR (cm−1): 3372 m, 2959 m, 1607 m, 1530 s, 1452 m, 1371s, 814 m, 751 m, 725 m.

{[Co(tbip)(bpp)(H2O)]2·4H2O} n (2). 2 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 6.0 with 1 M NaOH solution. Yield: 15.3 mg, 29%. Elemental analysis (%): calcd for C50H64Co2N4O14 C 56.48, H 6.07, N 5.27; found C 56.54, H 6.01, N 5.17. IR (cm−1): 3414 m, 2963 m, 1689 m, 1642 s, 1430 m, 1384 m, 1294 m, 908 m, 697 m.

The open channels encapsulate free H2tbip as guest molecules (Figure d,e). The effective free volume of 4 was calculated by PLATON analysis to be 14.4% of the crystal volume (990.1 out of the 6890.3 Å3 unit cell volume). It was noted that the 3D layer-pillared architecture was common in the assembly of porous coordination polymers with metal-carboxylate sheets always as layers and bidentate pyridyl as pillar ligands. It is rarely observed when bicarboxylate and bidentate pyridyl are simultaneously used to build 2D sheets.

Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted to study the thermal stability of 1−5, which is an important parameter for metal−organic framework materials (, ). The TGA curve for 1 suggested that the first weight loss of 31.82% in the region of 30−130 °C corresponded to the loss of eight lattice waters and six coordinated waters per formula unit (calcd. 31.12%). The residual framework started to decompose beyond 130 °C with a series of complicated weight losses and did not stop until heating ended at 750 °C. The TGA curve of 2 showed an initial weight loss of 12.86% below 320 °C corresponding to the removal of the solvent and coordinated water molecules (calcd. 10.17%), followed by a series of weight loss after that temperature. The TG curve of 3 showed that an initial weight loss in the temperature range 30−301 °C, which was due to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (weight loss of 3.69% (calcd. 3.65%)). The further weight loss represented the decomposition of the material. Complex 4 showed a weight loss of 11.1% below 270 °C, which closely matches the weight loss of 10.5% for removing half a H2tbip, half a guest water molecule, and one coordinated water molecule per formula unit from the framework, which is also in agreement with the results of elemental analysis.

Complex 5 exhibited no mass loss until ∼130 °C, at which point a series of mass losses ensued. Its mass remnant of 21.33% corresponded to CoO (calcd. 19.85%). To further test the stability of 4, we examined the powder samples by X-ray diffraction analysis. The structure was found to be stable after heating at 270 °C (, ), which indicates that the framework is stable after the loss of both free H2tbip guest molecules and coordinated water molecules.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1, 4, and 5 were measured in the 2−300 K temperature range, and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χM T products of 1 (Figure a) and 4 (Figure b) continuously decrease, which suggests that antiferromagnetic interactions are operative in 1 and 4. The experimental χM T values of 1 and 4 at room temperature are 2.81 and 4.68 cm3 K mol−1, respectively, which are larger than an uncoupled (1.87 cm3 K mol−1) and two isolated spin-only Co2+ cations (3.75 cm3 K mol−1). This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1 and 4 both obey the Curie−Weiss law above 50 K with θ = −34 K, C = 2.58 cm3·K/mol, R = 2.5 × 10−3 for 1 and θ = −26 K, C = 4.38 cm3·K/mol, R = 1.98 × 10−4 for 4. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin−orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The open channels encapsulate free H2tbip as guest molecules (Figure d,e). The effective free volume of 4 was calculated by PLATON analysis to be 14.4% of the crystal volume (990.1 out of the 6890.3 Å3 unit cell volume). It was noted that the 3D layer-pillared architecture was common in the assembly of porous coordination polymers with metal-carboxylate sheets always as layers and bidentate pyridyl as pillar ligands. It is rarely observed when bicarboxylate and bidentate pyridyl are simultaneously used to build 2D sheets.

Thermogravimetric experiments were conducted to study the thermal stability of 1-5, which is an important parameter for metal-organic framework materials (, ). The TGA curve for 1 suggested that the first weight loss of 31.82% in the region of 30-130 °C corresponded to the loss of eight lattice waters and six coordinated waters per formula unit (calcd. 31.12%). The residual framework started to decompose beyond 130 °C with a series of complicated weight losses and did not stop until heating ended at 750 °C. The TGA curve of 2 showed an initial weight loss of 12.86% below 320 °C corresponding to the removal of the solvent and coordinated water molecules (calcd. 10.17%), followed by a series of weight loss after that temperature. The TG curve of 3 showed that an initial weight loss in the temperature range 30-301 °C, which was due to the loss of one coordinated water molecule (weight loss of 3.69% (calcd. 3.65%)). The further weight loss represented the decomposition of the material. Complex 4 showed a weight loss of 11.1% below 270 °C, which closely matches the weight loss of 10.5% for removing half a H2tbip, half a guest water molecule, and one coordinated water molecule per formula unit from the framework, which is also in agreement with the results of elemental analysis.

Complex 5 exhibited no mass loss until ~130 °C, at which point a series of mass losses ensued. Its mass remnant of 21.33% corresponded to CoO (calcd. 19.85%). To further test the stability of 4, we examined the powder samples by X-ray diffraction analysis. The structure was found to be stable after heating at 270 °C (, ), which indicates that the framework is stable after the loss of both free H2tbip guest molecules and coordinated water molecules.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities, χM, of 1, 4, and 5 were measured in the 2-300 K temperature range, and shown as χM T and χM versus T plots in Figure . As the temperature is lowered to 2 K, the χM T products of 1 (Figure a) and 4 (Figure b) continuously decrease, which suggests that antiferromagnetic interactions are operative in 1 and 4. The experimental χM T values of 1 and 4 at room temperature are 2.81 and 4.68 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, which are larger than an uncoupled (1.87 cm3 K mol-1) and two isolated spin-only Co2+ cations (3.75 cm3 K mol-1). This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperature. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibilities (1/χM) of 1 and 4 both obey the Curie-Weiss law above 50 K with θ = -34 K, C = 2.58 cm3⋅K/mol, R = 2.5 × 10-3 for 1 and θ = -26 K, C = 4.38 cm3⋅K/mol, R = 1.98 × 10-4 for 4. The moderate negative θ values indicate the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions among adjacent Co(II) ions even if a contribution from the spin-orbit coupling of Co(II) is also present.
